comment._content: Good view of the former Nelson's Pillar.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Parnell monument was unveiled in July 1911, it looks nearly finished here.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The wagon with ads for a cinema/theatre on Gt. Brunswick St. is presumably for the Queen's Theatre on what is now Pearse St,, later temporary home of the Abbey. The Palace, later the Academy, was not a cinema until the 1920s. ’In England there is a growing demand for cinematograph entertainments’, announced Dublin’s Evening Mail in February 1908. ‘Every important town has its permanent “picture show”, and the Colonial Picture Combine see no reason why Ireland should not be adequately represented in this respect.’ The occasion of this statement was the opening of what was soon being advertised as the People’s Popular Picture Palace at the former Queen’s Theatre in Dublin’s Brunswick Street (now Pearse Street).

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Sign "CRANE" on the right, from the Lennon-Wylie page, the 1913 phone directory: Dublin 1574 Crane & Sons Ltd., Musical Instrument Manufacturers 40 Upper Sackville Street

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Technically, this bit of road is Cavendish Row, not Parnell Square. I wonder how long the horse trough at right lasted? [Edit] It is still there! Streetview
